DM BOT 04-04-2022 13:25
Everyone is in the main square of the Village of Barovia. There's a cacophony of ravens in the sky. One raven, carrying something, is being chased by a half dozen others. Seeing you on the street, a group of apparent adventures, it swoops and drives towards you, dropping the item. It almost smacks you in the head! Inside the paper wrapped parcel is a book. Its covers are cracked, unvarnished thin sheets of black oak covered with bird scratches and little indentations made by pecking beaks. Bound with black wire between these covers are thirty-three pages that have yellowed with age and wrinkled from moisture. Each page bears tiny, blotchy brown script written in an unsteady hand by an unidentified author. The Blood on the Vine tavern is there on the square, and it's easy to find a quiet alcove to review the book, as a group. The Book of the Raven is the firsthand account of an anonymous author who, after falling off her horse and breaking her leg, was rescued and befriended by Vistani travelers who graciously nursed her back to health. The author and her horse traveled with the Vistani for three months, during which the author spent most of her time laid up in a Vistani covered wagon, where she took to writing this book to pass the time. Although a dozen Vistani are colorfully described in the tome, only two are mentioned by name: Drasha, a teenaged girl who applied bandages and poultices to the author's wounded leg, and Darzin, a one-armed boy with a terrible fear of wolves who sang beautiful songs to help the author take her mind off the pain. (edited)
DM BOT 04-04-2022 13:25
The book provides a detailed account of the Vistani way of life, with emphasis on their food and music. Their overland journey is also discussed, albeit from the viewpoint of one who spent most of it inside a covered wagon. The author describes rough roads, days of travel through impenetrable mist and thick forest, crackling fires on cold nights, wolves howling in the dead of night, and ravens pecking at the roof of the wagon in the wee hours of the morning. Late in the book, the author writes of being able to hobble about on crutches. She describes the cheery mood of her benefactors as the Vistani caravan traveled a winding mountain road to the gates of a tall, dark castle. The book ends with a description of the castle's dreadful countenance. The writing abruptly stops on the third-to-last page, suggesting that the book was snatched from the author in mid-sentence. The last two pages are blank. Tucked in behind the last page, in the back cover, is a map. It's clear that the map was never part of the book to begin with. (edited)

Following Madam Eva's directions, with some expert guidance from Diana (once started on the right direction, with quick word from Vespyr), you make good time through the morning. You find the overgrown path Madam Eva indicated. But it's not completely overgrown. You pass a couple farmsteads along the river, most abandoned, but one with a distrustful looking farmer watching you as you pass. And you push on, the path parting from the river, until you get what might be Wytchway. Wytchway is only remains at this point. It was probably a small hamlet, perhaps a half dozen buildings. By your best guess, abandoned for nearly 40 years. The wooden structures are mostly fallen dawn, moss covering most of the piles of logs. A simple well has been dug in the center of the cluster of buildings - just a hole in the ground with a simple stone ring around it. In a bit better shape is the remains of a small church, with a low stone foundation and thick logs for the main supporting pillars. The roof has caved in. There looks to be a small graveyard next to it, judging by simple headstones in the tall grass.

She then looks up at Madrina, the woman is only a few years older than her and reminds her of her older sisters in the coven. thinking about everything that they had gone through, even discovering a way to possibly leave this realm for good. Diana's thoughts then drifts to the Baron's words to them Diana pulls out the paper she had been writing all of her notes about everything they had gone through in this place....even the existence of these people, and the shadow crossing and everything that happened in their brief excursion there with the Baron. she sighs, and walks to the stove, and stands in front of it for a moment before finally speaking "This paper holds records of what we've learned of this place and of the world beyond the grave." she say as she raises the paper on her hand for the others to see, her voice calm and composed Diana proceeds to throw the paper she had been writing on for the past weeks straight to the heart of the stove, its contents immediately consumed by the stove's flames she then turns to Madrina and the others, a calm look on her face "Is that proof enough?" she asks Madrina directly
